11243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-013-9722-8972210.1007/s11243-013-9722-8ArticleSyntheses and crystal structures of four silver(I) complexes of 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole or 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazolate: observation of Agtz3 and Ag4tz4 structural motifsLiuYa-Mei1YangShi-Tu1YanTing-Ting1YangHui1WeiXiu-Bao1YangGuang1fgrid.207374.50000000121893846College of Chemistry and Molecular EngineeringZhengzhou University450001ZhengzhouChinayang@zzu.edu.cn2442013820133855435511642013263201315420132442013© Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht 20132013Abstract

Three novel Ag(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole [4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz], namely {Ag2[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)2} (1), {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2), {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3), as well as one polymeric Ag(I) triazolate, {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4), have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray analyses show that 1–3 are discrete dinuclear, cyclic tetranuclear and mononuclear complexes, featuring Ag2tz2, Ag4tz4 and Agtz3 structural motifs in turn. 4 is a 3D coordination polymer with the Ag4tz4 clusters as the secondary building unit, the ant network can be extracted from the structure of 4.

Introduction

Metal 1,2,4-triazolates have attracted much attention for not only their intriguing structures, but also exceptional properties [1–7]. During the past several years, we have concentrated on the coordination chemistry of 1,2,4-triazole with Group 11 metals, especially in the structural aspect of the silver(I) complexes of 4-amino-3,5-disubstituted-4H-1,2,4-triazoles (4-NH2-3,5-R2tz) [8–13] and 3,5-disubstituted-4H-1,2,4-triazolates (3,5-R2tz−) [14–17]. For a series of silver(I) adducts with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz, Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn, where R = H, Me, Et, iPr, Bu, iBu, C5H11; X is a mono-valent counterion, several types of structural motifs have been recognized by us and others [18], including Agtz2, Ag2tz2, Ag3tz3, Ag3tz6, Ag4tz6-a and Ag4tz6-b, as shown in Scheme 1. Both the 3,5-substituents on the triazole ring and the anions have great influence on the formation and structures of the adducts. The ‘‘substituent effect’’ has been observed and discussed by us in the case of Ag4tz6-a/b several years ago: larger 3,5-substituents usually lead to an Ag4tz6-a arrangement, while smaller ones favor the formation of Ag4tz6-b clusters [12]. Steric repulsion between 3,5-groups, which will become prominent on coordination of triazole to metals, has been invoked to explain the observed trend.

Another type of complex we are interested in is silver(I) 1,2,4-triazolates. Unlike the neutral exo-bidentate 4-amino triazoles, the 1,2,4-triazolato anions (3,5-R2tz−), the deprotonated form of 3,5-R2tzH, function as even better polydentate ligands with rather flexible coordination patterns, due to the availability of the N4 atom for metals (the superscript on the N-atom indicates hereafter the position of N-atom on the triazole ring). As a result, silver(I) triazolates tend to adopt 1–3 D polymeric structures. We have noticed that polynuclear silver(I) triazolato clusters, usually formed by coordination of Ag atoms to N1 and N2 atoms of triazole, are frequently observed in these polymeric triazolates as the secondary building units (SBUs). Interestingly, some of these Ag-tz SBUs structurally resemble those Ag(I) adducts with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz. Furthermore, the ‘‘substituent effect’’ observed in molecular Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn seems still to be working well in the formation of polymeric silver triazolates, as demonstrated by a structural investigation of the correlation between Ag4tz6-a/b SBUs and the size of 3,5-substituents on triazole ring [14, 15, 17].

Continuing with our exploration of the ‘‘substituent effect’’ in metal 1,2,4-triazolates, we report herewith the synthesis of the 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl 1,2,4-triazole (4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz) and 3,5-dicyclohexyl 1,2,4-triazole (3,5-(C6H11)2tzH), as well as the structures of four of their silver(I) complexes. Three structural motifs, namely Ag2tz2, Ag4tz4 and Agtz3, were observed in {Ag2[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)2} (1), {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2) and {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3), respectively. A polymeric 3D silver(I) triazolate—{Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4)—was structurally determined to possess the Ag4tz4 cluster as the SBU; the topological net underlying the structure is ant, according to the nomenclature of three-letter symbol proposed by O’Keeffe and Yaghi [19]. The mechanism of substituent effect is also discussed here.

Results and discussionSyntheses and characterizations

4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole was prepared according to the literature method [20]. 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole was obtained by deamination of the corresponding 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole [21], as shown in Scheme 2. The identities of the two ligands have been verified by the elemental analysis and their 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S1, S2, S3, S4).

The complexes 1–4 were prepared by mixing the silver salts with the triazoles. The identities of the complexes have been verified by elemental analysis, IR spectra and 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S5-S10). The molar conductivity of 2 in CH3CN at 25 °C was measured to be 502 S cm2 mol−1, which matches well with the expected values for a 1:4 type electrolyte [22].

Crystal structure description

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Ag atom, one ligand and one nitrate (Fig. S11). By applying an inversion through the center of symmetry on the asymmetric unit, the complete molecular structure of 1 can be generated to be dinuclear in nature, featuring a six-membered (Ag–N–N–)2 ring, shown in Fig. 1. Each of the Ag atoms is four-coordinated by two triazole N atoms and two O atoms from one nitrate; each triazole bridges two Ag atoms as an exo-bidentate ligand (μ2–N1,N2), and the nitrates act as a chelating ligand to complete the coordination sphere of the Ag atom (η1,η1–O,O′). The distance between the two Ag atoms is 3.3333(6) Å, which is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the Ag atoms (3.44 Å), indicative of weak argentophilic interaction. Such a six-membered (Ag–N–N–)2 ring is frequently observed in other silver azolates, such as [Ag2(tzH)2(NO3)2] [23], [Ag2(4-NH2-3,5-Me2-tz)2(CF3COO)2] [24], [Ag2(4-NH2-3,5-iPr2-tz)2(NO3)2(CH3CN)] [13] and [(Ph3P)Ag(pz)]2 [25], (tzH = 4H-1,2,4-triazole; 4-NH2-3,5-Me2-tz = 4-amino-3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole; 4-NH2-3,5-iPr2-tz = 4-amino-3,5-diisopropyl-1,2,4-triazole; pz = pyrazolato anion).

{Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2) was prepared by the reaction of silver perchlorate and 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole in alcohol solution in the 1:1 molar ratio, which crystallizes in the monoclinic space group—P21/n. As shown in Fig. 2a, it is a tetranuclear compound, featuring an (Ag–N–N–)4 ring. Each Ag atom is nearly linearly coordinated by two N1 (or N2) atoms of two triazoles; however, if the weak Ag···O (ClO4−) bonds are counted in, the coordination geometry around Ag is better described as distorted tetrahedral. As in 1, each triazole acts as an exo-bidentate ligand in the common μ2–N1,N2 fashion. In the (Ag–N–N–)4 ring, four Ag atoms are approximately coplanar, forming a rhombus with the Ag···Ag distances in the range of 3.4967(15)–3.6974(15) Å, Ag–Ag–Ag angles of 85.624(30)–94.884(33)°. The four triazoles are placed alternately above and below the Ag4 plane, forming two “pockets” at both sides of Ag4. Interestingly, two of the four perchlorates in 2 are trapped in these pockets through weak Ag···O (ClO4−) bonds (Fig. 2b).

This kind of (Ag–N–N–)4 ring is also observed in a silver pyrazolate, [Ag(μ2-3,5-tBu2pz)]4 [26], and a silver triazolate, [Ag(μ2-3,5-tBu2tz)]4 [14]. The cyclic Ag4tz4 arrangement is closely related with our previously reported Ag4tz6-a cluster: If two triazoles, located loosely on the two sides of Ag4 plane of Ag4tz6-a cluster, were to be removed, an Ag4tz4 cluster would be generated and vice versa (Scheme 3). As we pointed out in our previous paper, the formation of Ag4tz6-a cluster by addition of two loosely linked triazoles to Ag4tz4 cluster reflects a tendency to gain a favorable enthalpy contribution and, in the meantime, minimize the entropy decrease [12]. Thus, the Ag4tz6-a arrangement is probably the result of a compromise between the two thermodynamic factors (∆H and ∆S). Possibly due to the bulk of the cyclohexyl group, it becomes impossible to insert additional triazoles into the pockets of 2. On the other hand, smaller perchlorates are more suited for these pockets and therefore trapped in them (Fig. S13). It is worthy of note that the Ag···O distances (2.64(2)–2.92(1) Å) are much longer than those of Ag–N, indicating the perchlorate anions are only weakly associated within the pockets of Ag4tz4 in the solid state. In accord with this observation in the crystal structure of 2 is the measurement of molar conductivity in acetonitrile, which shows 2 is a 1:4 type of electrolyte.

A comparison of the synthetic procedures and structures of 1 and 2 reveals the roles played by the counterions in determining the structures of Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn, which consist of altering the N–Ag–N angles of (Ag–N–N–)n rings and/or pre-organizing metals and ligands through the coordination of donor atoms of counterions to silver atoms. For 1 and other dinuclear complexes, a N–Ag–N angle of ca 120° is a crucial factor for the formation of a nearly planar six-membered (Ag–N–N–)2 ring.

In the presence of aqueous ammonia, a mononuclear complex {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3) was obtained by the reaction of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz with AgClO4 and crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. As shown in Fig. 3, the Ag atom is coordinated by three N1 (or N2) atoms from three triazoles, the distances of Ag–N are 2.192(4) Å, 2.219(4) Å and 2.272(4) Å, and the angles of N–Ag–N are 110.94(16)°, 114.65(16)° and 133.64(16)°. The Ag atom is about 0.11 Å above the triangle defined by three N donors; hence, they are virtually coplanar. Intermolecular H-bonds, involving the amino group and the N2 (or N1) atoms of triazole, might contribute to the stabilization of the observed structure (Fig. S18). Since the cyclohexyl groups clearly show a tendency to gather together, as evident by the shortest H···H distance of 2.6236(1) Å within the complex cation of 3, the hydrophobic interactions and/or the so-called dihydrogen interactions seem not negligible in the formation of 3 [27] (Figs. S19, S20). Although the three-coordinate Ag atom is known in the literature, 3 still represents the first observation of an Agtz3 motif in the series of silver(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-disubstituted-1,2,4-4H-triazoles.

{Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4) exhibits a 3D structure, which crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I41/a. The asymmetric unit of 4 is composed of one and a half Ag atoms, one 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazolate anion and half of a nitrate (Fig. S15). There are two types of Ag atoms, which are three- or four-coordinated in T-shaped (Ag1) and distorted tetrahedral (Ag2) coordination environments, respectively. The 3D structure of 4 features the Ag4tz4-SBU (Fig. 4a), formed by four Ag1 atoms and four triazoles utilizing their N1 and N2 atoms, similar to 2. Each of the Ag4tz4-SBU units is linked, from the N4 atoms of triazoles, with other four Ag4tz4-SBUs by the Ag2 atoms to form a 2D layer structure (Fig. 4b). The 2D layer structures of 4 are further connected together through the weak Ag2···O (NO3−) bonds, resulting in the final 3D structure (Ag2···O1i = 2.698(4) Å. i) 1.5 − x, 0.5 − y, 1.5 − z). The triazolate anions here act as a bridging ligand in the common μ3-N1,N2,N3 fashion, while the nitrates function in a rare “bridging plus chelating” μ3-η1:η1-O,O-η2-O′,O″ mode (Scheme 4). A packing diagram is shown in Fig. S16.

Interestingly enough, the constructive tactic for Ag4tz4-SBU in 4 is basically identical with that for Ag4tz4 cluster in 2. The difference between them lies in that two nitrates are now accommodated within the two pockets of Ag4tz4-SBU in 4. Due to the bridging mode of NO3−, each triazole ring is twisted a little as compared with those in Ag4tz4 cluster in 2. It seems that the structural features observed in silver(I) adduct with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz can be, more or less, transferred to or inherited by their triazolato (3,5-R2tz−) cousins, as evident by the case of Ag4tz4 cluster observed in 2 and 4 and other examples [12, 17, 28].

Analysis of the topology of <bold>4</bold>

As shown in Fig. 4b, the Ag4tz4 clusters are connected by Ag2 atoms to afford a 2D layer, which can be reduced to the well-known sql [19] or (4,4) net by taking Ag4tz4 as a four-connected node. If we take the weak Ag2···O bonds into consideration, then a 3D structure is generated in such a way that each Ag2 atom links to another layer in the direction opposite to that used by its four nearest neighbors. Clearly, the Ag4tz4 cluster now can be topologically considered as a six-connected node and the Ag2 atom as three-connected (Fig. 4c). Evaluating by “Systre,” the net underlying {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n is the binodal ant net [19]. Interestingly, the same topology has been observed in other silver triazolates such as Ag(3,5-Ph2-tz) and Ag[3,5-(CF3)2-tz] (3,5-Ph2-tz = 3,5-diphenyl-1,2,4-triazolate, 3,5-(CF3)2-tz = 3,5-di-trifluoromethyl-1,2,4-triazolate) [5, 17].

Structural role of the substituent

Upon coordination of triazoles to metals, the 3,5-substituents of triazoles are brought to close proximity. The steric repulsions between them were therefore our main concern to explore the structural role of the substituents. However, careful checking has revealed many short H···H contacts between substituents, as demonstrated by the complexes reported in this paper, which strongly suggest that attractive hydrophobic interactions or dihydrogen contacts might be there and contribute to stabilize the structures (Figs. S17, S20, S21, S22). The so-called substituent effect, frequently observed in many metal–triazole complexes, might operate through a delicate balance between the steric repulsions and some attractive forces like hydrophobic, dihydrogen contacts, and London dispersion forces.

Conclusions

Four silver(I) complexes with 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole or 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazolate have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Two new structural motifs, namely Agtz3 and Ag4tz4 clusters, have been recognized. The “substituent effect” manifests itself in the structures reported here, as exemplified by the observation of similar Ag4tz4 motifs in the discrete tetranuclear {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 and the polymeric {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n. Based on an analysis of the short H···H distances between adjacent cyclohexyl groups in these complexes, it is suggested the substituents act as a structural determinant through a delicate balance between the steric repulsions and some weak attractive forces existing among the substituents.

ExperimentalMaterials and measurements

Silver salts were purchased from Alfa Aesar; other commercially available reagents were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 420FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 400–4,000 cm−1. C, H, N microanalyses were performed with a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker DPX-400 spectrometer. The molar conductivities were measured with a DDB-303 portable conductivity meter.

Synthesis of 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-4H-1,2,4-triazole (4-NH<sub>2</sub>-3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tz)

Cyclohexanecarboxylic acid (0.02 mol, 2.56 g) and 80 % hydrazine hydrate (0.024 mol, 1.5 mL) were sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated in an oven at 180 °C for 72 h. The resulting viscous liquid was neutralized with dilute hydrochloric acid solution to pH ≈ 7, and then the mixture was filtered. The white solid crude product was recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of ethanol and water (v/v = 2:1), yielding colorless block crystals which were dried under vacuum. Yield: 85 %. Mp: 237–239 °C.

C14H24N4 (248.37) Found C 67.63, H 9.71, N 22.56; Calcd. C 67.70, H 9.74, N 22.56. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3,301 s (–NH2), 3,145 s (–NH2), 2,935 s, 2,852 s, 1,646 m, 1,508 s, 1,447 s, 1,440 w, 1,280 w, 1,198 w, 1,129 m, 1,054 w, 990 m, 936 w, 894 m, 826 w, 772 w, 718 w, 604 w, 504 w. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ = 5.73 (s, 2H, –NH2), 2.81 (m, 2H, –CH), 1.90–1.25 (m, 20H, –CH2–) ppm.

Synthesis of 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole (3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tzH)

To a stirred solution of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.01 mol, 2.48 g) in an aqueous solution of 50 % hypophosphorous acid (30 mL), an aqueous solution of sodium nitrite (0.05 mol 3.45 g in 10 mL of water) was added slowly with the temperature being maintained at 20–30 °C, during which vigorous nitrogen evolution was observed. After the addition was completed, the mixture was stirred for another 6 h at the same temperature. The resulting mixture was neutralized with 10 % NaOH solution to pH ≈ 7, from which a white precipitate emerged. Then, the white precipitate was collected and recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of methanol and water (v/v = 3:1) to yield a large quantity of colorless crystals. The product was then collected, dried under vacuum. Yield: 80 %. Mp: 140–142 °C.

C14H23N3 (233.35) Found C 71.77, H 10.07, N 18.16; Calcd. C 72.06, H 9.93, N 18.00. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 2,933 s, 2,852 s, 1,684 w, 1,566 m, 1,498 m, 1,450 m, 1,406 w, 1,272 w, 1,222 w, 1,180 w, 1,127 w, 1,066 w, 1,047 w, 993 w, 919 w, 892 w, 858 w, 780 w, 737 w, 584 w, 529 w. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ = 2.63 (m, 2H, –CH), 1.91–1.16 (m, 20H, –CH2–) ppm.

Synthesis of {Ag<sub>2</sub>[4-NH<sub>2</sub>-3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tz]<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>} (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of AgNO3 (0.025 mmol, 4.2 mg) in acetonitrile (2 mL) was added to an ethanol solution (2 mL) of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.025 mmol, 6.2 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate for 1 week to yield colorless needle crystals of 1, suitable for X-ray work. Yield: 45 %.

C28H48Ag2N10O6 (836.50) Found C 40.21, H 5.85, N 16.76; Calcd. C 40.27, H 5.80, N 16.79. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,343 s (–NH2), 3,278 m (–NH2), 2,928 s, 2,852 s, 1,653 w, 1,521 w, 1,508 w, 1,449 w, 1,384 s (NO3−), 1,130 w, 996 w, 894 w, 828 w, 768 w, 723 w, 618 w. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ = 5.98 (s, 2H, –NH2), 2.98–2.92 (m, 2H, –CH), 1.91–1.23 (m, 20H, –CH2–) ppm.

Synthesis of {Ag<sub>4</sub>[4-NH<sub>2</sub>-3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tz]<sub>4</sub>(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

An ethanol solution (2 mL) of AgClO4·H2O (0.025 mmol, 5.6 mg) was mixed with an ethanol (2 mL) solution of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.025 mmol, 6.2 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate for one day to yield colorless block crystals of 2. Yield: 60 %.

C56H96Ag4Cl4N16O16 (1,914.90) Found C 37.38, H 5.68, N 11.72; Calcd. C 37.00, H 5.33, N 12.34. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,357 s (–NH2), 3,293 s (–NH2), 3,232 w, 2,931 s, 2,853 s, 1,629 w, 1,535 w, 1,449 m, 1,302 s, 1,116 s (ClO4−), 1,093 s (ClO4−), 996 m, 922 w, 893 w, 828 w, 772 w, 736 w, 624 w, 580 w. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN): δ = 5.11 (s, 2H, –NH2), 3.02 (m, 2H, –CH), 1.88–1.28 (m, 20H, –CH2–) ppm. Molar conductivity (MeCN): Λm = 502 S·cm2·mol−1.

Synthesis of {Ag[4-NH<sub>2</sub>-3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tz]<sub>3</sub>}(ClO<sub>4</sub>) (<bold>3</bold>)

A solution containing AgClO4·H2O (0.025 mmol, 5.6 mg) and 25 % aqueous ammonia (0.5 mL) was mixed with a methanol solution (2 mL) of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.025 mmol, 6.2 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate slowly for three weeks to yield colorless block crystals of 3. Yield: 30 %.

C42H72AgClN12O4 (988.47) Found C 52.56, H 7.71, N 17.66; Calcd. C 53.04, H 7.63, N 17.68. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,364 s (–NH2), 3,289 m (–NH2), 2,962 s, 2,869 m, 1,616 m, 1,488 m, 1,463 m, 1,269 w, 1,097 s (ClO4−), 997 w, 928 w, 839 w, 752 w, 706 w, 624 m, 562 w.

Synthesis of {Ag<sub>3</sub>[3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tz]<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)}<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

An acetonitrile solution (2 mL) of AgNO3 (0.025 mmol, 4.2 mg) was mixed with an ethanol solution (2 mL) of 3,5-(C6H11)2tzH (0.025 mmol, 5.8 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate for six weeks to yield colorless block crystals of 4. Yield: 37 %.

C28H44Ag3N7O3 (850.31) Found C 39.55, H 5.22, N 11.53; Calcd. C 39.48, H 5.26, N 11.47. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 2,930 s, 2,854 s, 1,575 m, 1,522 m, 1,449 m, 1,386 w (NO3−), 1,232 w, 1,182 w, 1,135 w, 1,067 w, 1,040 w, 993 w, 894 w, 826 w, 767 w, 707 w, 523 w.

X-ray crystallography

Diffraction data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least square techniques using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs [29]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters; hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Crystallographic data for complexes 1–4 are summarized in Table 1.

CCDC 930792–930795 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for 1, 2, 3 and 4. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.clean_text: ]>This XML was provided by Springer Naturedoi:10.1007/s11243-013-9722-831aa4ebcea41b6792ab66adebe5119a0/kaist-api1110111243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-013-9722-8972210.1007/s11243-013-9722-8ArticleSyntheses and crystal structures of four silver(I) complexes of 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole or 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazolate: observation of Agtz3 and Ag4tz4 structural motifsLiuYa-Mei1YangShi-Tu1YanTing-Ting1YangHui1WeiXiu-Bao1YangGuang1f1grid.207374.50000000121893846College of Chemistry and Molecular EngineeringZhengzhou University450001ZhengzhouChinafyang@zzu.edu.cn2442013820133855435511642013263201315420132442013© Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht 20132013AbstractThree novel Ag(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole [4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz], namely {Ag2[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)2} (1), {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2), {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3), as well as one polymeric Ag(I) triazolate, {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4), have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray analyses show that 1-3 are discrete dinuclear, cyclic tetranuclear and mononuclear complexes, featuring Ag2tz2, Ag4tz4 and Agtz3 structural motifs in turn. 4 is a 3D coordination polymer with the Ag4tz4 clusters as the secondary building unit, the ant network can be extracted from the structure of 4.publisher-imprint-nameSpringervolume-issue-count8issue-article-count13issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2013issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media Dordrechtissue-copyright-year2013article-contains-esmYesarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2013article-registration-date-month4article-registration-date-day16article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productNonStandardArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/11243_2013_Article_9722.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2013issue-online-date-month7issue-online-date-day18issue-print-date-year2013issue-print-date-month7issue-print-date-day17issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryCatalysisjournal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistryjournal-subject-collectionChemistry and Materials Scienceopen-accessfalseElectronic supplementary materialThe online version of this article (doi:10.1007/s11243-013-9722-8) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.IntroductionMetal 1,2,4-triazolates have attracted much attention for not only their intriguing structures, but also exceptional properties [1-7]. During the past several years, we have concentrated on the coordination chemistry of 1,2,4-triazole with Group 11 metals, especially in the structural aspect of the silver(I) complexes of 4-amino-3,5-disubstituted-4H-1,2,4-triazoles (4-NH2-3,5-R2tz) [8-13] and 3,5-disubstituted-4H-1,2,4-triazolates (3,5-R2tz-) [14-17]. For a series of silver(I) adducts with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz, Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn, where R = H, Me, Et, iPr, Bu, iBu, C5H11; X is a mono-valent counterion, several types of structural motifs have been recognized by us and others [18], including Agtz2, Ag2tz2, Ag3tz3, Ag3tz6, Ag4tz6-a and Ag4tz6-b, as shown in Scheme 1. Both the 3,5-substituents on the triazole ring and the anions have great influence on the formation and structures of the adducts. The ‘‘substituent effect'' has been observed and discussed by us in the case of Ag4tz6-a/b several years ago: larger 3,5-substituents usually lead to an Ag4tz6-a arrangement, while smaller ones favor the formation of Ag4tz6-b clusters [12]. Steric repulsion between 3,5-groups, which will become prominent on coordination of triazole to metals, has been invoked to explain the observed trend.Another type of complex we are interested in is silver(I) 1,2,4-triazolates. Unlike the neutral exo-bidentate 4-amino triazoles, the 1,2,4-triazolato anions (3,5-R2tz-), the deprotonated form of 3,5-R2tzH, function as even better polydentate ligands with rather flexible coordination patterns, due to the availability of the N4 atom for metals (the superscript on the N-atom indicates hereafter the position of N-atom on the triazole ring). As a result, silver(I) triazolates tend to adopt 1-3 D polymeric structures. We have noticed that polynuclear silver(I) triazolato clusters, usually formed by coordination of Ag atoms to N1 and N2 atoms of triazole, are frequently observed in these polymeric triazolates as the secondary building units (SBUs). Interestingly, some of these Ag-tz SBUs structurally resemble those Ag(I) adducts with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz. Furthermore, the ‘‘substituent effect'' observed in molecular Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn seems still to be working well in the formation of polymeric silver triazolates, as demonstrated by a structural investigation of the correlation between Ag4tz6-a/b SBUs and the size of 3,5-substituents on triazole ring [14, 15, 17].Continuing with our exploration of the ‘‘substituent effect'' in metal 1,2,4-triazolates, we report herewith the synthesis of the 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl 1,2,4-triazole (4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz) and 3,5-dicyclohexyl 1,2,4-triazole (3,5-(C6H11)2tzH), as well as the structures of four of their silver(I) complexes. Three structural motifs, namely Ag2tz2, Ag4tz4 and Agtz3, were observed in {Ag2[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)2} (1), {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2) and {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3), respectively. A polymeric 3D silver(I) triazolate-{Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4)-was structurally determined to possess the Ag4tz4 cluster as the SBU; the topological net underlying the structure is ant, according to the nomenclature of three-letter symbol proposed by O'Keeffe and Yaghi [19]. The mechanism of substituent effect is also discussed here.Results and discussionSyntheses and characterizations4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole was prepared according to the literature method [20]. 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole was obtained by deamination of the corresponding 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole [21], as shown in Scheme 2. The identities of the two ligands have been verified by the elemental analysis and their 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S1, S2, S3, S4).The complexes 1-4 were prepared by mixing the silver salts with the triazoles. The identities of the complexes have been verified by elemental analysis, IR spectra and 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S5-S10). The molar conductivity of 2 in CH3CN at 25 °C was measured to be 502 S cm2 mol-1, which matches well with the expected values for a 1:4 type electrolyte [22].Crystal structure descriptionSingle-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Ag atom, one ligand and one nitrate (Fig. S11). By applying an inversion through the center of symmetry on the asymmetric unit, the complete molecular structure of 1 can be generated to be dinuclear in nature, featuring a six-membered (Ag-N-N-)2 ring, shown in Fig. 1. Each of the Ag atoms is four-coordinated by two triazole N atoms and two O atoms from one nitrate; each triazole bridges two Ag atoms as an exo-bidentate ligand (μ2-N1,N2), and the nitrates act as a chelating ligand to complete the coordination sphere of the Ag atom (η1,η1-O,O'). The distance between the two Ag atoms is 3.3333(6) Å, which is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the Ag atoms (3.44 Å), indicative of weak argentophilic interaction. Such a six-membered (Ag-N-N-)2 ring is frequently observed in other silver azolates, such as [Ag2(tzH)2(NO3)2] [23], [Ag2(4-NH2-3,5-Me2-tz)2(CF3COO)2] [24], [Ag2(4-NH2-3,5-iPr2-tz)2(NO3)2(CH3CN)] [13] and [(Ph3P)Ag(pz)]2 [25], (tzH = 4H-1,2,4-triazole; 4-NH2-3,5-Me2-tz = 4-amino-3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole; 4-NH2-3,5-iPr2-tz = 4-amino-3,5-diisopropyl-1,2,4-triazole; pz = pyrazolato anion).{Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2) was prepared by the reaction of silver perchlorate and 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole in alcohol solution in the 1:1 molar ratio, which crystallizes in the monoclinic space group-P21/n. As shown in Fig. 2a, it is a tetranuclear compound, featuring an (Ag-N-N-)4 ring. Each Ag atom is nearly linearly coordinated by two N1 (or N2) atoms of two triazoles; however, if the weak Ag⋅⋅⋅O (ClO4-) bonds are counted in, the coordination geometry around Ag is better described as distorted tetrahedral. As in 1, each triazole acts as an exo-bidentate ligand in the common μ2-N1,N2 fashion. In the (Ag-N-N-)4 ring, four Ag atoms are approximately coplanar, forming a rhombus with the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances in the range of 3.4967(15)-3.6974(15) Å, Ag-Ag-Ag angles of 85.624(30)-94.884(33)°. The four triazoles are placed alternately above and below the Ag4 plane, forming two "pockets" at both sides of Ag4. Interestingly, two of the four perchlorates in 2 are trapped in these pockets through weak Ag⋅⋅⋅O (ClO4-) bonds (Fig. 2b).This kind of (Ag-N-N-)4 ring is also observed in a silver pyrazolate, [Ag(μ2-3,5-tBu2pz)]4 [26], and a silver triazolate, [Ag(μ2-3,5-tBu2tz)]4 [14]. The cyclic Ag4tz4 arrangement is closely related with our previously reported Ag4tz6-a cluster: If two triazoles, located loosely on the two sides of Ag4 plane of Ag4tz6-a cluster, were to be removed, an Ag4tz4 cluster would be generated and vice versa (Scheme 3). As we pointed out in our previous paper, the formation of Ag4tz6-a cluster by addition of two loosely linked triazoles to Ag4tz4 cluster reflects a tendency to gain a favorable enthalpy contribution and, in the meantime, minimize the entropy decrease [12]. Thus, the Ag4tz6-a arrangement is probably the result of a compromise between the two thermodynamic factors (∆H and ∆S). Possibly due to the bulk of the cyclohexyl group, it becomes impossible to insert additional triazoles into the pockets of 2. On the other hand, smaller perchlorates are more suited for these pockets and therefore trapped in them (Fig. S13). It is worthy of note that the Ag⋅⋅⋅O distances (2.64(2)-2.92(1) Å) are much longer than those of Ag-N, indicating the perchlorate anions are only weakly associated within the pockets of Ag4tz4 in the solid state. In accord with this observation in the crystal structure of 2 is the measurement of molar conductivity in acetonitrile, which shows 2 is a 1:4 type of electrolyte.A comparison of the synthetic procedures and structures of 1 and 2 reveals the roles played by the counterions in determining the structures of Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn, which consist of altering the N-Ag-N angles of (Ag-N-N-)n rings and/or pre-organizing metals and ligands through the coordination of donor atoms of counterions to silver atoms. For 1 and other dinuclear complexes, a N-Ag-N angle of ca 120° is a crucial factor for the formation of a nearly planar six-membered (Ag-N-N-)2 ring.In the presence of aqueous ammonia, a mononuclear complex {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3) was obtained by the reaction of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz with AgClO4 and crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. As shown in Fig. 3, the Ag atom is coordinated by three N1 (or N2) atoms from three triazoles, the distances of Ag-N are 2.192(4) Å, 2.219(4) Å and 2.272(4) Å, and the angles of N-Ag-N are 110.94(16)°, 114.65(16)° and 133.64(16)°. The Ag atom is about 0.11 Å above the triangle defined by three N donors; hence, they are virtually coplanar. Intermolecular H-bonds, involving the amino group and the N2 (or N1) atoms of triazole, might contribute to the stabilization of the observed structure (Fig. S18). Since the cyclohexyl groups clearly show a tendency to gather together, as evident by the shortest H⋅⋅⋅H distance of 2.6236(1) Å within the complex cation of 3, the hydrophobic interactions and/or the so-called dihydrogen interactions seem not negligible in the formation of 3 [27] (Figs. S19, S20). Although the three-coordinate Ag atom is known in the literature, 3 still represents the first observation of an Agtz3 motif in the series of silver(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-disubstituted-1,2,4-4H-triazoles.{Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4) exhibits a 3D structure, which crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I41/a. The asymmetric unit of 4 is composed of one and a half Ag atoms, one 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazolate anion and half of a nitrate (Fig. S15). There are two types of Ag atoms, which are three- or four-coordinated in T-shaped (Ag1) and distorted tetrahedral (Ag2) coordination environments, respectively. The 3D structure of 4 features the Ag4tz4-SBU (Fig. 4a), formed by four Ag1 atoms and four triazoles utilizing their N1 and N2 atoms, similar to 2. Each of the Ag4tz4-SBU units is linked, from the N4 atoms of triazoles, with other four Ag4tz4-SBUs by the Ag2 atoms to form a 2D layer structure (Fig. 4b). The 2D layer structures of 4 are further connected together through the weak Ag2⋅⋅⋅O (NO3-) bonds, resulting in the final 3D structure (Ag2⋅⋅⋅O1i = 2.698(4) Å. i) 1.5 - x, 0.5 - y, 1.5 - z). The triazolate anions here act as a bridging ligand in the common μ3-N1,N2,N3 fashion, while the nitrates function in a rare "bridging plus chelating" μ3-η1:η1-O,O-η2-O',O" mode (Scheme 4). A packing diagram is shown in Fig. S16.Interestingly enough, the constructive tactic for Ag4tz4-SBU in 4 is basically identical with that for Ag4tz4 cluster in 2. The difference between them lies in that two nitrates are now accommodated within the two pockets of Ag4tz4-SBU in 4. Due to the bridging mode of NO3-, each triazole ring is twisted a little as compared with those in Ag4tz4 cluster in 2. It seems that the structural features observed in silver(I) adduct with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz can be, more or less, transferred to or inherited by their triazolato (3,5-R2tz-) cousins, as evident by the case of Ag4tz4 cluster observed in 2 and 4 and other examples [12, 17, 28].Analysis of the topology of 4As shown in Fig. 4b, the Ag4tz4 clusters are connected by Ag2 atoms to afford a 2D layer, which can be reduced to the well-known sql [19] or (4,4) net by taking Ag4tz4 as a four-connected node. If we take the weak Ag2⋅⋅⋅O bonds into consideration, then a 3D structure is generated in such a way that each Ag2 atom links to another layer in the direction opposite to that used by its four nearest neighbors. Clearly, the Ag4tz4 cluster now can be topologically considered as a six-connected node and the Ag2 atom as three-connected (Fig. 4c). Evaluating by "Systre," the net underlying {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n is the binodal ant net [19]. Interestingly, the same topology has been observed in other silver triazolates such as Ag(3,5-Ph2-tz) and Ag[3,5-(CF3)2-tz] (3,5-Ph2-tz = 3,5-diphenyl-1,2,4-triazolate, 3,5-(CF3)2-tz = 3,5-di-trifluoromethyl-1,2,4-triazolate) [5, 17].Structural role of the substituentUpon coordination of triazoles to metals, the 3,5-substituents of triazoles are brought to close proximity. The steric repulsions between them were therefore our main concern to explore the structural role of the substituents. However, careful checking has revealed many short H⋅⋅⋅H contacts between substituents, as demonstrated by the complexes reported in this paper, which strongly suggest that attractive hydrophobic interactions or dihydrogen contacts might be there and contribute to stabilize the structures (Figs. S17, S20, S21, S22). The so-called substituent effect, frequently observed in many metal-triazole complexes, might operate through a delicate balance between the steric repulsions and some attractive forces like hydrophobic, dihydrogen contacts, and London dispersion forces.ConclusionsFour silver(I) complexes with 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole or 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazolate have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Two new structural motifs, namely Agtz3 and Ag4tz4 clusters, have been recognized. The "substituent effect" manifests itself in the structures reported here, as exemplified by the observation of similar Ag4tz4 motifs in the discrete tetranuclear {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 and the polymeric {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n. Based on an analysis of the short H⋅⋅⋅H distances between adjacent cyclohexyl groups in these complexes, it is suggested the substituents act as a structural determinant through a delicate balance between the steric repulsions and some weak attractive forces existing among the substituents.ExperimentalMaterials and measurementsSilver salts were purchased from Alfa Aesar; other commercially available reagents were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 420FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 400-4,000 cm-1. C, H, N microanalyses were performed with a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker DPX-400 spectrometer. The molar conductivities were measured with a DDB-303 portable conductivity meter.Synthesis of 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-4H-1,2,4-triazole (4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz)Cyclohexanecarboxylic acid (0.02 mol, 2.56 g) and 80 % hydrazine hydrate (0.024 mol, 1.5 mL) were sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated in an oven at 180 °C for 72 h. The resulting viscous liquid was neutralized with dilute hydrochloric acid solution to pH ~ 7, and then the mixture was filtered. The white solid crude product was recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of ethanol and water (v/v = 2:1), yielding colorless block crystals which were dried under vacuum. Yield: 85 %. Then, the white precipitate was collected and recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of methanol and water (v/v = 3:1) to yield a large quantity of colorless crystals. elements.content: Three novel Ag(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole [4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz], namely {Ag2[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)2} (1), {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2), {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3), as well as one polymeric Ag(I) triazolate, {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4), have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray analyses show that 1–3 are discrete dinuclear, cyclic tetranuclear and mononuclear complexes, featuring Ag2tz2, Ag4tz4 and Agtz3 structural motifs in turn. 4 is a 3D coordination polymer with the Ag4tz4 clusters as the secondary building unit, the ant network can be extracted from the structure of 4.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three novel Ag(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole [4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz], namely {Ag2[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)2} (1), {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2), {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3), as well as one polymeric Ag(I) triazolate, {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4), have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray analyses show that 1-3 are discrete dinuclear, cyclic tetranuclear and mononuclear complexes, featuring Ag2tz2, Ag4tz4 and Agtz3 structural motifs in turn. 4 is a 3D coordination polymer with the Ag4tz4 clusters as the secondary building unit, the ant network can be extracted from the structure of 4.

elements.content: Metal 1,2,4-triazolates have attracted much attention for not only their intriguing structures, but also exceptional properties [1–7]. During the past several years, we have concentrated on the coordination chemistry of 1,2,4-triazole with Group 11 metals, especially in the structural aspect of the silver(I) complexes of 4-amino-3,5-disubstituted-4H-1,2,4-triazoles (4-NH2-3,5-R2tz) [8–13] and 3,5-disubstituted-4H-1,2,4-triazolates (3,5-R2tz−) [14–17]. For a series of silver(I) adducts with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz, Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn, where R = H, Me, Et, iPr, Bu, iBu, C5H11; X is a mono-valent counterion, several types of structural motifs have been recognized by us and others [18], including Agtz2, Ag2tz2, Ag3tz3, Ag3tz6, Ag4tz6-a and Ag4tz6-b, as shown in Scheme 1. Both the 3,5-substituents on the triazole ring and the anions have great influence on the formation and structures of the adducts. The ‘‘substituent effect’’ has been observed and discussed by us in the case of Ag4tz6-a/b several years ago: larger 3,5-substituents usually lead to an Ag4tz6-a arrangement, while smaller ones favor the formation of Ag4tz6-b clusters [12]. Steric repulsion between 3,5-groups, which will become prominent on coordination of triazole to metals, has been invoked to explain the observed trend.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal 1,2,4-triazolates have attracted much attention for not only their intriguing structures, but also exceptional properties [1-7]. During the past several years, we have concentrated on the coordination chemistry of 1,2,4-triazole with Group 11 metals, especially in the structural aspect of the silver(I) complexes of 4-amino-3,5-disubstituted-4H-1,2,4-triazoles (4-NH2-3,5-R2tz) [8-13] and 3,5-disubstituted-4H-1,2,4-triazolates (3,5-R2tz-) [14-17]. For a series of silver(I) adducts with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz, Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn, where R = H, Me, Et, iPr, Bu, iBu, C5H11; X is a mono-valent counterion, several types of structural motifs have been recognized by us and others [18], including Agtz2, Ag2tz2, Ag3tz3, Ag3tz6, Ag4tz6-a and Ag4tz6-b, as shown in Scheme 1. Both the 3,5-substituents on the triazole ring and the anions have great influence on the formation and structures of the adducts. The ‘‘substituent effect'' has been observed and discussed by us in the case of Ag4tz6-a/b several years ago: larger 3,5-substituents usually lead to an Ag4tz6-a arrangement, while smaller ones favor the formation of Ag4tz6-b clusters [12]. Steric repulsion between 3,5-groups, which will become prominent on coordination of triazole to metals, has been invoked to explain the observed trend.

elements.content: Another type of complex we are interested in is silver(I) 1,2,4-triazolates. Unlike the neutral exo-bidentate 4-amino triazoles, the 1,2,4-triazolato anions (3,5-R2tz−), the deprotonated form of 3,5-R2tzH, function as even better polydentate ligands with rather flexible coordination patterns, due to the availability of the N4 atom for metals (the superscript on the N-atom indicates hereafter the position of N-atom on the triazole ring). As a result, silver(I) triazolates tend to adopt 1–3 D polymeric structures. We have noticed that polynuclear silver(I) triazolato clusters, usually formed by coordination of Ag atoms to N1 and N2 atoms of triazole, are frequently observed in these polymeric triazolates as the secondary building units (SBUs). Interestingly, some of these Ag-tz SBUs structurally resemble those Ag(I) adducts with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz. Furthermore, the ‘‘substituent effect’’ observed in molecular Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn seems still to be working well in the formation of polymeric silver triazolates, as demonstrated by a structural investigation of the correlation between Ag4tz6-a/b SBUs and the size of 3,5-substituents on triazole ring [14, 15, 17].
elements.clean_text: Another type of complex we are interested in is silver(I) 1,2,4-triazolates. Unlike the neutral exo-bidentate 4-amino triazoles, the 1,2,4-triazolato anions (3,5-R2tz-), the deprotonated form of 3,5-R2tzH, function as even better polydentate ligands with rather flexible coordination patterns, due to the availability of the N4 atom for metals (the superscript on the N-atom indicates hereafter the position of N-atom on the triazole ring). As a result, silver(I) triazolates tend to adopt 1-3 D polymeric structures. We have noticed that polynuclear silver(I) triazolato clusters, usually formed by coordination of Ag atoms to N1 and N2 atoms of triazole, are frequently observed in these polymeric triazolates as the secondary building units (SBUs). Interestingly, some of these Ag-tz SBUs structurally resemble those Ag(I) adducts with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz. Furthermore, the ‘‘substituent effect'' observed in molecular Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn seems still to be working well in the formation of polymeric silver triazolates, as demonstrated by a structural investigation of the correlation between Ag4tz6-a/b SBUs and the size of 3,5-substituents on triazole ring [14, 15, 17].

elements.content: Continuing with our exploration of the ‘‘substituent effect’’ in metal 1,2,4-triazolates, we report herewith the synthesis of the 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl 1,2,4-triazole (4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz) and 3,5-dicyclohexyl 1,2,4-triazole (3,5-(C6H11)2tzH), as well as the structures of four of their silver(I) complexes. Three structural motifs, namely Ag2tz2, Ag4tz4 and Agtz3, were observed in {Ag2[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)2} (1), {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2) and {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3), respectively. A polymeric 3D silver(I) triazolate—{Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4)—was structurally determined to possess the Ag4tz4 cluster as the SBU; the topological net underlying the structure is ant, according to the nomenclature of three-letter symbol proposed by O’Keeffe and Yaghi [19]. The mechanism of substituent effect is also discussed here.

Three structural motifs, namely Ag2tz2, Ag4tz4 and Agtz3, were observed in {Ag2[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)2} (1), {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2) and {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3), respectively. A polymeric 3D silver(I) triazolate-{Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4)-was structurally determined to possess the Ag4tz4 cluster as the SBU; the topological net underlying the structure is ant, according to the nomenclature of three-letter symbol proposed by O'Keeffe and Yaghi [19]. The mechanism of substituent effect is also discussed here.

elements.content: 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole was prepared according to the literature method [20]. 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole was obtained by deamination of the corresponding 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole [21], as shown in Scheme 2. The identities of the two ligands have been verified by the elemental analysis and their 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S1, S2, S3, S4).
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Syntheses and characterizations

4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole was prepared according to the literature method [20]. 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole was obtained by deamination of the corresponding 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole [21], as shown in Scheme 2. The identities of the two ligands have been verified by the elemental analysis and their 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S1, S2, S3, S4).

elements.content: The complexes 1–4 were prepared by mixing the silver salts with the triazoles. The identities of the complexes have been verified by elemental analysis, IR spectra and 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S5-S10). The molar conductivity of 2 in CH3CN at 25 °C was measured to be 502 S cm2 mol−1, which matches well with the expected values for a 1:4 type electrolyte [22].

The identities of the complexes have been verified by elemental analysis, IR spectra and 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S5-S10). The molar conductivity of 2 in CH3CN at 25 °C was measured to be 502 S cm2 mol-1, which matches well with the expected values for a 1:4 type electrolyte [22].

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Ag atom, one ligand and one nitrate (Fig. S11). By applying an inversion through the center of symmetry on the asymmetric unit, the complete molecular structure of 1 can be generated to be dinuclear in nature, featuring a six-membered (Ag–N–N–)2 ring, shown in Fig. 1. Each of the Ag atoms is four-coordinated by two triazole N atoms and two O atoms from one nitrate; each triazole bridges two Ag atoms as an exo-bidentate ligand (μ2–N1,N2), and the nitrates act as a chelating ligand to complete the coordination sphere of the Ag atom (η1,η1–O,O′). The distance between the two Ag atoms is 3.3333(6) Å, which is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the Ag atoms (3.44 Å), indicative of weak argentophilic interaction. Such a six-membered (Ag–N–N–)2 ring is frequently observed in other silver azolates, such as [Ag2(tzH)2(NO3)2] [23], [Ag2(4-NH2-3,5-Me2-tz)2(CF3COO)2] [24], [Ag2(4-NH2-3,5-iPr2-tz)2(NO3)2(CH3CN)] [13] and [(Ph3P)Ag(pz)]2 [25], (tzH = 4H-1,2,4-triazole; 4-NH2-3,5-Me2-tz = 4-amino-3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole; 4-NH2-3,5-iPr2-tz = 4-amino-3,5-diisopropyl-1,2,4-triazole; pz = pyrazolato anion).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure description

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Ag atom, one ligand and one nitrate (Fig. S11). By applying an inversion through the center of symmetry on the asymmetric unit, the complete molecular structure of 1 can be generated to be dinuclear in nature, featuring a six-membered (Ag-N-N-)2 ring, shown in Fig. 1. Each of the Ag atoms is four-coordinated by two triazole N atoms and two O atoms from one nitrate; each triazole bridges two Ag atoms as an exo-bidentate ligand (μ2-N1,N2), and the nitrates act as a chelating ligand to complete the coordination sphere of the Ag atom (η1,η1-O,O'). The distance between the two Ag atoms is 3.3333(6) Å, which is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the Ag atoms (3.44 Å), indicative of weak argentophilic interaction. Such a six-membered (Ag-N-N-)2 ring is frequently observed in other silver azolates, such as [Ag2(tzH)2(NO3)2] [23], [Ag2(4-NH2-3,5-Me2-tz)2(CF3COO)2] [24], [Ag2(4-NH2-3,5-iPr2-tz)2(NO3)2(CH3CN)] [13] and [(Ph3P)Ag(pz)]2 [25], (tzH = 4H-1,2,4-triazole; 4-NH2-3,5-Me2-tz = 4-amino-3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole; 4-NH2-3,5-iPr2-tz = 4-amino-3,5-diisopropyl-1,2,4-triazole; pz = pyrazolato anion).

elements.content: {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 (2) was prepared by the reaction of silver perchlorate and 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole in alcohol solution in the 1:1 molar ratio, which crystallizes in the monoclinic space group—P21/n. As shown in Fig. 2a, it is a tetranuclear compound, featuring an (Ag–N–N–)4 ring. Each Ag atom is nearly linearly coordinated by two N1 (or N2) atoms of two triazoles; however, if the weak Ag···O (ClO4−) bonds are counted in, the coordination geometry around Ag is better described as distorted tetrahedral. As in 1, each triazole acts as an exo-bidentate ligand in the common μ2–N1,N2 fashion. In the (Ag–N–N–)4 ring, four Ag atoms are approximately coplanar, forming a rhombus with the Ag···Ag distances in the range of 3.4967(15)–3.6974(15) Å, Ag–Ag–Ag angles of 85.624(30)–94.884(33)°. The four triazoles are placed alternately above and below the Ag4 plane, forming two “pockets” at both sides of Ag4. Interestingly, two of the four perchlorates in 2 are trapped in these pockets through weak Ag···O (ClO4−) bonds (Fig. 2b).

As shown in Fig. 2a, it is a tetranuclear compound, featuring an (Ag-N-N-)4 ring. Each Ag atom is nearly linearly coordinated by two N1 (or N2) atoms of two triazoles; however, if the weak Ag⋅⋅⋅O (ClO4-) bonds are counted in, the coordination geometry around Ag is better described as distorted tetrahedral. As in 1, each triazole acts as an exo-bidentate ligand in the common μ2-N1,N2 fashion. In the (Ag-N-N-)4 ring, four Ag atoms are approximately coplanar, forming a rhombus with the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances in the range of 3.4967(15)-3.6974(15) Å, Ag-Ag-Ag angles of 85.624(30)-94.884(33)°. The four triazoles are placed alternately above and below the Ag4 plane, forming two "pockets" at both sides of Ag4. Interestingly, two of the four perchlorates in 2 are trapped in these pockets through weak Ag⋅⋅⋅O (ClO4-) bonds (Fig. 2b).

elements.content: a The ball-and-stick diagram of the {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4}4+ in 2. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. b A side view of the Ag4tz4 cluster associated with two ClO4− anions. Selected distances (Å) and angles(°): Ag1···Ag2, 3.6974(15); Ag2···Ag3, 3.6497(14); Ag3···Ag4, 3.4967(15); Ag1···Ag4, 3.6275(15); Ag1–N3, 2.151(9); Ag1–N8, 2.182(9); Ag2–N4, 2.154(9); Ag3–N12, 2.137(9); Ag3–N16, 2.146(9); Ag4–N7, 2.108(9); Ag4–N11, 2.125(9); Ag1···O2, 2.8476(161); Ag2···O4, 2.9150(148); Ag3···O4, 2.7996(145); Ag4···O2, 2.7131(136); Ag1···O6, 2.6353(223); Ag2···O6, 2.6385(234); Ag3···O5, 2.8643(204); Ag4···O5, 2.7191(220); N3–Ag1–N8, 171.8(4); N7–Ag4–N11, 166.0(4); N4–Ag2–N15, 170.3(3); N12–Ag3–N16, 169.9(4)

This kind of (Ag–N–N–)4 ring is also observed in a silver pyrazolate, [Ag(μ2-3,5-tBu2pz)]4 [26], and a silver triazolate, [Ag(μ2-3,5-tBu2tz)]4 [14]. The cyclic Ag4tz4 arrangement is closely related with our previously reported Ag4tz6-a cluster: If two triazoles, located loosely on the two sides of Ag4 plane of Ag4tz6-a cluster, were to be removed, an Ag4tz4 cluster would be generated and vice versa (Scheme 3). As we pointed out in our previous paper, the formation of Ag4tz6-a cluster by addition of two loosely linked triazoles to Ag4tz4 cluster reflects a tendency to gain a favorable enthalpy contribution and, in the meantime, minimize the entropy decrease [12]. Thus, the Ag4tz6-a arrangement is probably the result of a compromise between the two thermodynamic factors (∆H and ∆S). Possibly due to the bulk of the cyclohexyl group, it becomes impossible to insert additional triazoles into the pockets of 2. On the other hand, smaller perchlorates are more suited for these pockets and therefore trapped in them (Fig. S13). It is worthy of note that the Ag···O distances (2.64(2)–2.92(1) Å) are much longer than those of Ag–N, indicating the perchlorate anions are only weakly associated within the pockets of Ag4tz4 in the solid state. In accord with this observation in the crystal structure of 2 is the measurement of molar conductivity in acetonitrile, which shows 2 is a 1:4 type of electrolyte.

elements.content: A comparison of the synthetic procedures and structures of 1 and 2 reveals the roles played by the counterions in determining the structures of Agn(4-NH2-3,5-R2tz)mXn, which consist of altering the N–Ag–N angles of (Ag–N–N–)n rings and/or pre-organizing metals and ligands through the coordination of donor atoms of counterions to silver atoms. For 1 and other dinuclear complexes, a N–Ag–N angle of ca 120° is a crucial factor for the formation of a nearly planar six-membered (Ag–N–N–)2 ring.

For 1 and other dinuclear complexes, a N-Ag-N angle of ca 120° is a crucial factor for the formation of a nearly planar six-membered (Ag-N-N-)2 ring.

elements.content: In the presence of aqueous ammonia, a mononuclear complex {Ag[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]3}(ClO4) (3) was obtained by the reaction of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz with AgClO4 and crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. As shown in Fig. 3, the Ag atom is coordinated by three N1 (or N2) atoms from three triazoles, the distances of Ag–N are 2.192(4) Å, 2.219(4) Å and 2.272(4) Å, and the angles of N–Ag–N are 110.94(16)°, 114.65(16)° and 133.64(16)°. The Ag atom is about 0.11 Å above the triangle defined by three N donors; hence, they are virtually coplanar. Intermolecular H-bonds, involving the amino group and the N2 (or N1) atoms of triazole, might contribute to the stabilization of the observed structure (Fig. S18). Since the cyclohexyl groups clearly show a tendency to gather together, as evident by the shortest H···H distance of 2.6236(1) Å within the complex cation of 3, the hydrophobic interactions and/or the so-called dihydrogen interactions seem not negligible in the formation of 3 [27] (Figs. S19, S20). Although the three-coordinate Ag atom is known in the literature, 3 still represents the first observation of an Agtz3 motif in the series of silver(I) adducts with 4-amino-3,5-disubstituted-1,2,4-4H-triazoles.

elements.content: {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n (4) exhibits a 3D structure, which crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I41/a. The asymmetric unit of 4 is composed of one and a half Ag atoms, one 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazolate anion and half of a nitrate (Fig. S15). There are two types of Ag atoms, which are three- or four-coordinated in T-shaped (Ag1) and distorted tetrahedral (Ag2) coordination environments, respectively. The 3D structure of 4 features the Ag4tz4-SBU (Fig. 4a), formed by four Ag1 atoms and four triazoles utilizing their N1 and N2 atoms, similar to 2. Each of the Ag4tz4-SBU units is linked, from the N4 atoms of triazoles, with other four Ag4tz4-SBUs by the Ag2 atoms to form a 2D layer structure (Fig. 4b). The 2D layer structures of 4 are further connected together through the weak Ag2···O (NO3−) bonds, resulting in the final 3D structure (Ag2···O1i = 2.698(4) Å. i) 1.5 − x, 0.5 − y, 1.5 − z). The triazolate anions here act as a bridging ligand in the common μ3-N1,N2,N3 fashion, while the nitrates function in a rare “bridging plus chelating” μ3-η1:η1-O,O-η2-O′,O″ mode (Scheme 4). A packing diagram is shown in Fig. S16.

elements.content: Interestingly enough, the constructive tactic for Ag4tz4-SBU in 4 is basically identical with that for Ag4tz4 cluster in 2. The difference between them lies in that two nitrates are now accommodated within the two pockets of Ag4tz4-SBU in 4. Due to the bridging mode of NO3−, each triazole ring is twisted a little as compared with those in Ag4tz4 cluster in 2. It seems that the structural features observed in silver(I) adduct with 4-NH2-3,5-R2tz can be, more or less, transferred to or inherited by their triazolato (3,5-R2tz−) cousins, as evident by the case of Ag4tz4 cluster observed in 2 and 4 and other examples [12, 17, 28].

elements.content: As shown in Fig. 4b, the Ag4tz4 clusters are connected by Ag2 atoms to afford a 2D layer, which can be reduced to the well-known sql [19] or (4,4) net by taking Ag4tz4 as a four-connected node. If we take the weak Ag2···O bonds into consideration, then a 3D structure is generated in such a way that each Ag2 atom links to another layer in the direction opposite to that used by its four nearest neighbors. Clearly, the Ag4tz4 cluster now can be topologically considered as a six-connected node and the Ag2 atom as three-connected (Fig. 4c). Evaluating by “Systre,” the net underlying {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n is the binodal ant net [19]. Interestingly, the same topology has been observed in other silver triazolates such as Ag(3,5-Ph2-tz) and Ag[3,5-(CF3)2-tz] (3,5-Ph2-tz = 3,5-diphenyl-1,2,4-triazolate, 3,5-(CF3)2-tz = 3,5-di-trifluoromethyl-1,2,4-triazolate) [5, 17].
elements.clean_text:
Analysis of the topology of 4

As shown in Fig. 4b, the Ag4tz4 clusters are connected by Ag2 atoms to afford a 2D layer, which can be reduced to the well-known sql [19] or (4,4) net by taking Ag4tz4 as a four-connected node. If we take the weak Ag2⋅⋅⋅O bonds into consideration, then a 3D structure is generated in such a way that each Ag2 atom links to another layer in the direction opposite to that used by its four nearest neighbors. Clearly, the Ag4tz4 cluster now can be topologically considered as a six-connected node and the Ag2 atom as three-connected (Fig. 4c). Evaluating by "Systre," the net underlying {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n is the binodal ant net [19]. Interestingly, the same topology has been observed in other silver triazolates such as Ag(3,5-Ph2-tz) and Ag[3,5-(CF3)2-tz] (3,5-Ph2-tz = 3,5-diphenyl-1,2,4-triazolate, 3,5-(CF3)2-tz = 3,5-di-trifluoromethyl-1,2,4-triazolate) [5, 17].

elements.content: Upon coordination of triazoles to metals, the 3,5-substituents of triazoles are brought to close proximity. The steric repulsions between them were therefore our main concern to explore the structural role of the substituents. However, careful checking has revealed many short H···H contacts between substituents, as demonstrated by the complexes reported in this paper, which strongly suggest that attractive hydrophobic interactions or dihydrogen contacts might be there and contribute to stabilize the structures (Figs. S17, S20, S21, S22). The so-called substituent effect, frequently observed in many metal–triazole complexes, might operate through a delicate balance between the steric repulsions and some attractive forces like hydrophobic, dihydrogen contacts, and London dispersion forces.
elements.clean_text:
Structural role of the substituent

Upon coordination of triazoles to metals, the 3,5-substituents of triazoles are brought to close proximity. The steric repulsions between them were therefore our main concern to explore the structural role of the substituents. However, careful checking has revealed many short H⋅⋅⋅H contacts between substituents, as demonstrated by the complexes reported in this paper, which strongly suggest that attractive hydrophobic interactions or dihydrogen contacts might be there and contribute to stabilize the structures (Figs. S17, S20, S21, S22). The so-called substituent effect, frequently observed in many metal-triazole complexes, might operate through a delicate balance between the steric repulsions and some attractive forces like hydrophobic, dihydrogen contacts, and London dispersion forces.

elements.content: Four silver(I) complexes with 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole or 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazolate have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Two new structural motifs, namely Agtz3 and Ag4tz4 clusters, have been recognized. The “substituent effect” manifests itself in the structures reported here, as exemplified by the observation of similar Ag4tz4 motifs in the discrete tetranuclear {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 and the polymeric {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n. Based on an analysis of the short H···H distances between adjacent cyclohexyl groups in these complexes, it is suggested the substituents act as a structural determinant through a delicate balance between the steric repulsions and some weak attractive forces existing among the substituents.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Four silver(I) complexes with 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole or 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazolate have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Two new structural motifs, namely Agtz3 and Ag4tz4 clusters, have been recognized. The "substituent effect" manifests itself in the structures reported here, as exemplified by the observation of similar Ag4tz4 motifs in the discrete tetranuclear {Ag4[4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz]4(ClO4)2}(ClO4)2 and the polymeric {Ag3[3,5-(C6H11)2tz]2(NO3)}n. Based on an analysis of the short H⋅⋅⋅H distances between adjacent cyclohexyl groups in these complexes, it is suggested the substituents act as a structural determinant through a delicate balance between the steric repulsions and some weak attractive forces existing among the substituents.

elements.content: Silver salts were purchased from Alfa Aesar; other commercially available reagents were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 420FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 400–4,000 cm−1. C, H, N microanalyses were performed with a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker DPX-400 spectrometer. The molar conductivities were measured with a DDB-303 portable conductivity meter.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and measurements

Silver salts were purchased from Alfa Aesar; other commercially available reagents were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 420FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 400-4,000 cm-1. C, H, N microanalyses were performed with a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker DPX-400 spectrometer. The molar conductivities were measured with a DDB-303 portable conductivity meter.

elements.content: Cyclohexanecarboxylic acid (0.02 mol, 2.56 g) and 80 % hydrazine hydrate (0.024 mol, 1.5 mL) were sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated in an oven at 180 °C for 72 h. The resulting viscous liquid was neutralized with dilute hydrochloric acid solution to pH ≈ 7, and then the mixture was filtered. The white solid crude product was recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of ethanol and water (v/v = 2:1), yielding colorless block crystals which were dried under vacuum. Yield: 85 %. Mp: 237–239 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 4-amino-3,5-dicyclohexyl-4H-1,2,4-triazole (4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz)

Cyclohexanecarboxylic acid (0.02 mol, 2.56 g) and 80 % hydrazine hydrate (0.024 mol, 1.5 mL) were sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated in an oven at 180 °C for 72 h. The resulting viscous liquid was neutralized with dilute hydrochloric acid solution to pH ~ 7, and then the mixture was filtered. The white solid crude product was recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of ethanol and water (v/v = 2:1), yielding colorless block crystals which were dried under vacuum. Yield: 85 %. Mp: 237-239 °C.

elements.content: To a stirred solution of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.01 mol, 2.48 g) in an aqueous solution of 50 % hypophosphorous acid (30 mL), an aqueous solution of sodium nitrite (0.05 mol 3.45 g in 10 mL of water) was added slowly with the temperature being maintained at 20–30 °C, during which vigorous nitrogen evolution was observed. After the addition was completed, the mixture was stirred for another 6 h at the same temperature. The resulting mixture was neutralized with 10 % NaOH solution to pH ≈ 7, from which a white precipitate emerged. Then, the white precipitate was collected and recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of methanol and water (v/v = 3:1) to yield a large quantity of colorless crystals. The product was then collected, dried under vacuum. Yield: 80 %. Mp: 140–142 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole (3,5-(C6H11)2tzH)

To a stirred solution of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.01 mol, 2.48 g) in an aqueous solution of 50 % hypophosphorous acid (30 mL), an aqueous solution of sodium nitrite (0.05 mol 3.45 g in 10 mL of water) was added slowly with the temperature being maintained at 20-30 °C, during which vigorous nitrogen evolution was observed. After the addition was completed, the mixture was stirred for another 6 h at the same temperature. The resulting mixture was neutralized with 10 % NaOH solution to pH ~ 7, from which a white precipitate emerged. Then, the white precipitate was collected and recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of methanol and water (v/v = 3:1) to yield a large quantity of colorless crystals. The product was then collected, dried under vacuum. Yield: 80 %. Mp: 140-142 °C.

elements.content: A solution of AgNO3 (0.025 mmol, 4.2 mg) in acetonitrile (2 mL) was added to an ethanol solution (2 mL) of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.025 mmol, 6.2 mg). elements.content: Diffraction data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least square techniques using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs [29]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters; hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Crystallographic data for complexes 1–4 are summarized in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Diffraction data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least square techniques using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs [29]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters; hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Crystallographic data for complexes 1-4 are summarized in Table 1.

cln_elements.content:
Cyclohexanecarboxylic acid (0.02 mol, 2.56 g) and 80 % hydrazine hydrate (0.024 mol, 1.5 mL) were sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated in an oven at 180 °C for 72 h. The resulting viscous liquid was neutralized with dilute hydrochloric acid solution to pH ≈ 7, and then the mixture was filtered. The white solid crude product was recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of ethanol and water (v/v = 2:1), yielding colorless block crystals which were dried under vacuum. Yield: 85 %. Mp: 237–239 °C.

Synthesis of 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole (3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tzH)

To a stirred solution of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.01 mol, 2.48 g) in an aqueous solution of 50 % hypophosphorous acid (30 mL), an aqueous solution of sodium nitrite (0.05 mol 3.45 g in 10 mL of water) was added slowly with the temperature being maintained at 20–30 °C, during which vigorous nitrogen evolution was observed. After the addition was completed, the mixture was stirred for another 6 h at the same temperature. The resulting mixture was neutralized with 10 % NaOH solution to pH ≈ 7, from which a white precipitate emerged. Then, the white precipitate was collected and recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of methanol and water (v/v = 3:1) to yield a large quantity of colorless crystals. The product was then collected, dried under vacuum. Yield: 80 %. Mp: 140–142 °C.

Synthesis of {Ag<sub>2</sub>[4-NH<sub>2</sub>-3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tz]<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>} (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of AgNO3 (0.025 mmol, 4.2 mg) in acetonitrile (2 mL) was added to an ethanol solution (2 mL) of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.025 mmol, 6.2 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate for 1 week to yield colorless needle crystals of 1, suitable for X-ray work. Yield: 45 %.

Synthesis of {Ag<sub>4</sub>[4-NH<sub>2</sub>-3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tz]<sub>4</sub>(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

An ethanol solution (2 mL) of AgClO4·H2O (0.025 mmol, 5.6 mg) was mixed with an ethanol (2 mL) solution of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.025 mmol, 6.2 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate for one day to yield colorless block crystals of 2. Yield: 60 %.

Synthesis of {Ag[4-NH<sub>2</sub>-3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tz]<sub>3</sub>}(ClO<sub>4</sub>) (<bold>3</bold>)

A solution containing AgClO4·H2O (0.025 mmol, 5.6 mg) and 25 % aqueous ammonia (0.5 mL) was mixed with a methanol solution (2 mL) of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.025 mmol, 6.2 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate slowly for three weeks to yield colorless block crystals of 3. Yield: 30 %.

C42H72AgClN12O4 (988.47) Found C 52.56, H 7.71, N 17.66; Calcd. C 53.04, H 7.63, N 17.68. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,364 s (–NH2), 3,289 m (–NH2), 2,962 s, 2,869 m, 1,616 m, 1,488 m, 1,463 m, 1,269 w, 1,097 s (ClO4−), 997 w, 928 w, 839 w, 752 w, 706 w, 624 m, 562 w.

Synthesis of {Ag<sub>3</sub>[3,5-(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>11</sub>)<sub>2</sub>tz]<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)}<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

An acetonitrile solution (2 mL) of AgNO3 (0.025 mmol, 4.2 mg) was mixed with an ethanol solution (2 mL) of 3,5-(C6H11)2tzH (0.025 mmol, 5.8 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate for six weeks to yield colorless block crystals of 4. Yield: 37 %.

C28H44Ag3N7O3 (850.31) Found C 39.55, H 5.22, N 11.53; Calcd. C 39.48, H 5.26, N 11.47. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 2,930 s, 2,854 s, 1,575 m, 1,522 m, 1,449 m, 1,386 w (NO3−), 1,232 w, 1,182 w, 1,135 w, 1,067 w, 1,040 w, 993 w, 894 w, 826 w, 767 w, 707 w, 523 w.

The resulting viscous liquid was neutralized with dilute hydrochloric acid solution to pH ~ 7, and then the mixture was filtered. The white solid crude product was recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of ethanol and water (v/v = 2:1), yielding colorless block crystals which were dried under vacuum. Yield: 85 %. Mp: 237-239 °C.

Synthesis of 3,5-dicyclohexyl-1,2,4-triazole (3,5-(C6H11)2tzH)

To a stirred solution of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.01 mol, 2.48 g) in an aqueous solution of 50 % hypophosphorous acid (30 mL), an aqueous solution of sodium nitrite (0.05 mol 3.45 g in 10 mL of water) was added slowly with the temperature being maintained at 20-30 °C, during which vigorous nitrogen evolution was observed. The resulting mixture was neutralized with 10 % NaOH solution to pH ~ 7, from which a white precipitate emerged. Then, the white precipitate was collected and recrystallized from a mixed solvent composed of methanol and water (v/v = 3:1) to yield a large quantity of colorless crystals. A solution containing AgClO4⋅H2O (0.025 mmol, 5.6 mg) and 25 % aqueous ammonia (0.5 mL) was mixed with a methanol solution (2 mL) of 4-NH2-3,5-(C6H11)2tz (0.025 mmol, 6.2 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate slowly for three weeks to yield colorless block crystals of 3. Yield: 30 %.

An acetonitrile solution (2 mL) of AgNO3 (0.025 mmol, 4.2 mg) was mixed with an ethanol solution (2 mL) of 3,5-(C6H11)2tzH (0.025 mmol, 5.8 mg). The resulting mixture was allowed to evaporate for six weeks to yield colorless block crystals of 4. Yield: 37 %.

C28H44Ag3N7O3 (850.31) Found C 39.55, H 5.22, N 11.53; Calcd. C 39.48, H 5.26, N 11.47. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2,930 s, 2,854 s, 1,575 m, 1,522 m, 1,449 m, 1,386 w (NO3-), 1,232 w, 1,182 w, 1,135 w, 1,067 w, 1,040 w, 993 w, 894 w, 826 w, 767 w, 707 w, 523 w.

cln_elements.content:
The complexes 1–4 were prepared by mixing the silver salts with the triazoles. The identities of the complexes have been verified by elemental analysis, IR spectra and 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S5-S10). The molar conductivity of 2 in CH3CN at 25 °C was measured to be 502 S cm2 mol−1, which matches well with the expected values for a 1:4 type electrolyte [22].

C28H48Ag2N10O6 (836.50) Found C 40.21, H 5.85, N 16.76; Calcd. C 40.27, H 5.80, N 16.79. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,343 s (–NH2), 3,278 m (–NH2), 2,928 s, 2,852 s, 1,653 w, 1,521 w, 1,508 w, 1,449 w, 1,384 s (NO3−), 1,130 w, 996 w, 894 w, 828 w, 768 w, 723 w, 618 w. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ = 5.98 (s, 2H, –NH2), 2.98–2.92 (m, 2H, –CH), 1.91–1.23 (m, 20H, –CH2–) ppm.

C56H96Ag4Cl4N16O16 (1,914.90) Found C 37.38, H 5.68, N 11.72; Calcd. C 37.00, H 5.33, N 12.34. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,357 s (–NH2), 3,293 s (–NH2), 3,232 w, 2,931 s, 2,853 s, 1,629 w, 1,535 w, 1,449 m, 1,302 s, 1,116 s (ClO4−), 1,093 s (ClO4−), 996 m, 922 w, 893 w, 828 w, 772 w, 736 w, 624 w, 580 w. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN): δ = 5.11 (s, 2H, –NH2), 3.02 (m, 2H, –CH), 1.88–1.28 (m, 20H, –CH2–) ppm. Molar conductivity (MeCN): Λm = 502 S·cm2·mol−1.
